description: Adobe Premiere Pro Creative Cloud is used by video professionals and enthusiasts to edit and export their projects.  It is timeline-based and can sync multiple camera tracks while using advanced built-in styles and templates to add title sequences and lighting/camera effects. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Premiere Pro CC
subtitle: Video Editing Application

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James introduce you to Adobe's Premiere Pro initial user interface. They walk you through opening Premiere for the first time and creating a new project. They also show you the general project settings and user control preferences. Finally they explore the audio settings, media types and syncing with the Adobe Creative Cloud.
episodes.title: Opening and Initial Settings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.918 --> 00:00:13.824
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3
00:00:13.824 --> 00:00:16.520
welcome to another great
episode of ITPro TV.

4
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:17.550
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

5
00:00:17.550 --> 00:00:21.290
in today's episode we are kicking
off our Premiere Pro series.

6
00:00:21.290 --> 00:00:25.060
Joining us in the studio to lend
his expertise on that very topic

7
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:26.500
is our good friend, Mr. James Biddle.

8
00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:28.010
James, welcome to the show, sir.

9
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:28.980
We're so glad to have you today.

10
00:00:28.980 --> 00:00:30.440
How's it going?
>> Dan, it's great to be here,

11
00:00:30.440 --> 00:00:32.138
but
>> I like you.

12
00:00:32.138 --> 00:00:34.463
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I like Adobe Premiere,

13
00:00:34.463 --> 00:00:37.116
even more [CROSSTALK] I’m
just gonna go ahead and

14
00:00:37.116 --> 00:00:41.780
get started and I wanna talk to everybody
about just opening up Adobe Premiere Pro.

15
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:45.390
And getting into the settings.

16
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:48.370
Adobe does a really good
job of setting this up so

17
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:52.910
you have the ability to just get started
but you might want to change some stuff.

18
00:00:52.910 --> 00:00:55.630
And they're also very good
at letting you personalize.

19
00:00:55.630 --> 00:00:58.130
The thing I like to do is
look at the pretty pictures.

20
00:00:58.130 --> 00:01:00.380
I love that adobe puts these great
pictures on here to sort of inspire

21
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:03.600
Inspire to get into editing.

22
00:01:03.600 --> 00:01:05.820
All right.
So here's our opening screen.

23
00:01:05.820 --> 00:01:07.630
Whenever you open any of the suite,

24
00:01:07.630 --> 00:01:11.700
you get a screen like this to
ask you what do you want to do?

25
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:14.610
And it's more than just open a project or
start a new project.

26
00:01:14.610 --> 00:01:16.728
Notice I can get into recent projects,

27
00:01:16.728 --> 00:01:19.150
it will say,
your recent work will appear here.

28
00:01:19.150 --> 00:01:20.802
So if you've already been
working on something,

29
00:01:20.802 --> 00:01:22.030
it just appears right there for you.

30
00:01:22.030 --> 00:01:23.570
You get to started.

31
00:01:23.570 --> 00:01:26.850
I can ask a quick question especially
if there have been any updates.

32
00:01:26.850 --> 00:01:29.630
We all know now with a creative Cloud,
you get a lot of updates.

33
00:01:29.630 --> 00:01:33.560
You have missed something, so you can
jump right in and found out what was new.

34
00:01:33.560 --> 00:01:35.340
I can check on my Cloud account.

35
00:01:35.340 --> 00:01:36.970
But let me quit rambling.

36
00:01:36.970 --> 00:01:37.690
Let's just get started.

37
00:01:37.690 --> 00:01:39.750
I'm gonna start a new project.

38
00:01:39.750 --> 00:01:40.530
Okay.

39
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:45.620
So anytime you get lost in
any of the panels, okay?

40
00:01:45.620 --> 00:01:47.880
I'm calling this big
guy right here a panel.

41
00:01:47.880 --> 00:01:50.773
Anytime you get lost in a panel,
go right to the top gray bar, and

42
00:01:50.773 --> 00:01:52.336
it will tell you what's going on.

43
00:01:52.336 --> 00:01:53.610
A new project.

44
00:01:53.610 --> 00:01:57.420
That's fairly simple,
coming down, we want to name it.

45
00:01:57.420 --> 00:01:59.270
Please don't leave it untitled.

46
00:01:59.270 --> 00:02:02.610
If you've seen me here,
do it for me, okay?

47
00:02:02.610 --> 00:02:03.850
Name your pets.

48
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:06.890
Cat, dog, you know a great moniker,
but you know, Fluffy.

49
00:02:06.890 --> 00:02:08.030
Something like that.

50
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:09.540
And make it something
that you can remember and

51
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:11.740
maybe it's a little specific
to what you're doing.

52
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:16.060
So untitled number 927 is so
fairly non descriptive.

53
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:17.090
It's not gonna be very helpful.

54
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:20.370
>> It's non descriptive,
but I've seen untitled 927.

55
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:22.280
It looks a lot like 928.

56
00:02:22.280 --> 00:02:23.160
So, here we go.

57
00:02:23.160 --> 00:02:25.690
I'm just gonna call this IT PRO TV.

58
00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:30.440
Give it a little underscore, and
just say, premier lesson, okay?

59
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:33.400
And that way,
I know exactly what's going on.

60
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:34.800
Now where's it gonna go?

61
00:02:34.800 --> 00:02:37.330
Adobe does a great job with defaults,
again, so

62
00:02:37.330 --> 00:02:40.770
you don't have to think about certain
things, but you may want to change it.

63
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:45.850
Right now, I really don't want it going to
this hard drive under this default area,

64
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:49.600
so I will choose browse, and
I will say I want to put it on this

65
00:02:49.600 --> 00:02:54.630
External drive that I brought, and
just call it Lessons, all right?

66
00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:57.760
That way, I'm gonna remember it, and
I have it on my own private drive.

67
00:02:59.290 --> 00:03:02.870
Once we get down here, these are some
settings that you may wanna explore later

68
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:05.120
about video rendering and playback.

69
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:10.360
Adobe gives you options so that you can
use the graphics processing card for

70
00:03:10.360 --> 00:03:15.390
a lot of your previews and depending on
your type of computer and your graphics

71
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:20.770
card you may be able to, like,
we like to say, like scream through this.

72
00:03:20.770 --> 00:03:23.740
So we have one here and
we'll be able to use it today.

73
00:03:25.080 --> 00:03:28.830
These three,
you can change a lot of this at any time.

74
00:03:28.830 --> 00:03:34.130
If you don't do it now, Adobe always
offers you the opportunity to do it later.

75
00:03:34.130 --> 00:03:38.210
So when I'm working with video, I'll be
able to do time code or I can see feet and

76
00:03:38.210 --> 00:03:41.550
frames or just frames depending
on what I'm working on.

77
00:03:41.550 --> 00:03:43.480
Audio, usually display format.

78
00:03:43.480 --> 00:03:44.670
Audio samples is fine.

79
00:03:44.670 --> 00:03:47.659
If you're somebody that's really into
beats, you might want to do milliseconds.

80
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:51.160
Also the capture format.

81
00:03:51.160 --> 00:03:55.790
Capture is specifically when you
come from one medium to another.

82
00:03:55.790 --> 00:03:58.310
And now you may have worked with
tape before, Dan, I don't know.

83
00:03:58.310 --> 00:04:00.760
But if you do tape and

84
00:04:00.760 --> 00:04:06.090
come in, that's where this capture
preset can be very, very important.

85
00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:08.930
If you're just coming out of
card-based media, you're coming off and

86
00:04:08.930 --> 00:04:11.770
drive, this really doesn't
matter in the beginning.

87
00:04:11.770 --> 00:04:16.800
Also, you can display the project item
name and label color for all instances.

88
00:04:16.800 --> 00:04:18.470
And notice when I do that,
it gives me a little,

89
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:23.120
it gives me a little heads up to say,
if this item is checked, names and

90
00:04:23.120 --> 00:04:26.740
label colors will match
the corresponding project item.

91
00:04:27.990 --> 00:04:31.210
That may sound a little over descriptive.

92
00:04:31.210 --> 00:04:34.640
Adobe gives you that over description
because then when you actually do this,

93
00:04:34.640 --> 00:04:36.510
you can say now I know what they mean.

94
00:04:37.630 --> 00:04:38.600
Scratch Disks.

95
00:04:39.680 --> 00:04:42.480
Here's what they're saying is
if you are capturing items,

96
00:04:42.480 --> 00:04:45.160
you're coming off of a tape or
maybe you're doing film.

97
00:04:45.160 --> 00:04:47.240
Congratulations if you are.

98
00:04:47.240 --> 00:04:50.860
Where will the files be located?

99
00:04:50.860 --> 00:04:52.220
In most cases,

100
00:04:52.220 --> 00:04:56.882
captured video, not going to matter cuz
you're probably using card based media.

101
00:04:56.882 --> 00:05:00.520
If you're coming off of tapes or
films, you're gonna have to set this.

102
00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:04.970
Right now it's gonna default to all
these default, same as project.

103
00:05:04.970 --> 00:05:08.110
So where that project file is located, and

104
00:05:08.110 --> 00:05:12.720
it tells me right here,
volumes, my drive, and lessons.

105
00:05:12.720 --> 00:05:15.650
Everything's going to go right there.

106
00:05:15.650 --> 00:05:18.640
For today, I'm just gonna go ahead and
leave that for these lessons.

107
00:05:18.640 --> 00:05:20.680
I can route it to anywhere I want to.

108
00:05:20.680 --> 00:05:23.690
I can route it to another drive,
I've known people who have tried,

109
00:05:23.690 --> 00:05:27.600
you know I'm going to do it to Dropbox at
the same time, or something like that.

110
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:29.420
And you know it works just well.

111
00:05:29.420 --> 00:05:31.100
You can experiment with this.

112
00:05:31.100 --> 00:05:34.890
As long as you know where it was,
you can retrieve it.

113
00:05:34.890 --> 00:05:39.958
The only one that I generally
set in here is captured audio.

114
00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:44.280
Now I'm be pulling off a tape or anything
like that and I have some audio on a card.

115
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:48.110
The reason I do this, is there is
a nice voice over feature in here,

116
00:05:48.110 --> 00:05:50.690
where I can read through my laptop or

117
00:05:50.690 --> 00:05:55.070
it's a little board unto a microphone and
I'll get an audio file.

118
00:05:55.070 --> 00:05:58.540
The way that Adobe premier
knows how to place that file

119
00:05:58.540 --> 00:06:01.745
is by using this captured audio setting.

120
00:06:01.745 --> 00:06:05.251
I can leave it same as project, and
it will know exactly where it is or

121
00:06:05.251 --> 00:06:08.995
maybe a special audio
folder that I wanna design.

122
00:06:08.995 --> 00:06:11.925
If not, I'm just gonna leave
everything where it is.

123
00:06:11.925 --> 00:06:17.360
Then the one that I usually like to change
a lot, is called project auto save, what

124
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:23.070
this means is, I'm about to create that
little file, that little project file.

125
00:06:23.070 --> 00:06:25.580
I double-click it, it opens and I get it.

126
00:06:25.580 --> 00:06:26.130
>> Magic.

127
00:06:26.130 --> 00:06:27.654
>> Magic.
>> [LAUGH]

128
00:06:28.910 --> 00:06:30.520
>> Something might happen,

129
00:06:30.520 --> 00:06:33.330
it might explode,
sometimes things get corrupt.

130
00:06:33.330 --> 00:06:38.780
So Adobe offers me this great option
to say hey, if you forgot to save or

131
00:06:38.780 --> 00:06:43.660
you're not saving enough,
at a certain period in time,

132
00:06:43.660 --> 00:06:47.950
we will create an autosaved backup for
you.

133
00:06:47.950 --> 00:06:50.110
And generally, you can do it like
every five minutes, every ten minutes,

134
00:06:50.110 --> 00:06:51.970
every two hours, whatever you want.

135
00:06:51.970 --> 00:06:55.560
And you can put it right next to
where your projects are located.

136
00:06:55.560 --> 00:06:58.685
Or like I do,
I send it to an to another drive.

137
00:06:58.685 --> 00:07:01.445
So that way, if the project and
the autosave are on the same drive and

138
00:07:01.445 --> 00:07:04.475
something goes kablooie,
I just lost all my autosaves.

139
00:07:04.475 --> 00:07:07.395
>> So the good people at Adobe have
realized the fact that we, as humans,

140
00:07:07.395 --> 00:07:12.187
aren't really great about saving our
work before Something critical occurs.

141
00:07:12.187 --> 00:07:14.907
>> Or even better,
because Adobe is so exciting and

142
00:07:14.907 --> 00:07:19.017
you just wanna edit, why not just
have an automated process to do it?

143
00:07:19.017 --> 00:07:23.591
So I'm thinking about [CROSSTALK] Yeah,
I'll think about the story I'm telling.

144
00:07:23.591 --> 00:07:27.391
Instead of the saving, and
it's like okay, that's great.

145
00:07:27.391 --> 00:07:31.053
I love that, so
I will send that to something else,

146
00:07:31.053 --> 00:07:34.023
also it's one of those things,
maybe I'm working and working and working,

147
00:07:34.023 --> 00:07:39.130
and then I realize, okay,
this thing I just made Is terrible.

148
00:07:39.130 --> 00:07:43.140
But two weeks ago,
I made this thing that was amazing and

149
00:07:43.140 --> 00:07:46.780
if I go back in the autosaves,
I can get it from there.

150
00:07:46.780 --> 00:07:47.998
It's like it's brilliant.

151
00:07:47.998 --> 00:07:49.165
>> That's nice.
>> Love it and it's like,

152
00:07:49.165 --> 00:07:50.630
okay here's some more for two weeks or so,

153
00:07:50.630 --> 00:07:52.314
even better and
I'll start working from there.

154
00:07:52.314 --> 00:07:53.058
Okay?

155
00:07:53.058 --> 00:07:57.098
You also have the ability to do
Creative Cloud library downloads.

156
00:07:57.098 --> 00:07:59.117
And I'm gonna show you
some of those later,

157
00:07:59.117 --> 00:08:03.240
cuz I made a couple in a side program
that's for free, that I did on my phone.

158
00:08:03.240 --> 00:08:06.690
And I can load that library
into Adobe Premier.

159
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:09.370
So, once I have this done,
all I have to do is click OK.

160
00:08:09.370 --> 00:08:11.580
And then we get the exciting part.

161
00:08:11.580 --> 00:08:13.050
We get the interface.

162
00:08:13.050 --> 00:08:16.004
And it's like, yes, and there's all
the windows I can get all my stuff in.

163
00:08:16.004 --> 00:08:17.720
But then it's like I
better check some stuff.

164
00:08:19.120 --> 00:08:21.910
And what that checking stuff is,
I come up to the top menu bar and

165
00:08:21.910 --> 00:08:25.750
I go to Premier Pro > CC and
I go to Preferences.

166
00:08:25.750 --> 00:08:28.419
You are gonna see there are a lot of them.

167
00:08:29.480 --> 00:08:34.380
Now, Adobe is a wonderful dense program,
and I have been using it for

168
00:08:34.380 --> 00:08:35.190
a very long time.

169
00:08:35.190 --> 00:08:38.250
And, technically,
I am a certified expert instructor.

170
00:08:38.250 --> 00:08:41.640
But there are some things in
this that I have never used

171
00:08:41.640 --> 00:08:45.730
because they are very specialized for
certain types of work.

172
00:08:45.730 --> 00:08:48.562
I mean, I've tried them,
I've demoed them and I've used them, but

173
00:08:48.562 --> 00:08:50.270
I don't use them on daily basis.

174
00:08:50.270 --> 00:08:52.403
That's why there are a lot of settings.

175
00:08:52.403 --> 00:08:58.200
Some of them you will set, some of them
you will only look at at a specific time.

176
00:08:58.200 --> 00:09:02.170
The most important one is the top one.

177
00:09:02.170 --> 00:09:03.760
Come here,
let's get to the right one there.

178
00:09:03.760 --> 00:09:05.220
Thank you Biddle.

179
00:09:05.220 --> 00:09:07.670
We're gonna go right to general, okay?

180
00:09:07.670 --> 00:09:12.250
And this is the most important
one that we are going to look at.

181
00:09:12.250 --> 00:09:16.140
Now [BLANK AUDIO] Starting at the top and
working our way to the bottom.

182
00:09:16.140 --> 00:09:21.960
I often tell people, if you get lost, top
to bottom left to right, front to back.

183
00:09:21.960 --> 00:09:25.420
Just like like you read a book, just
go at this like you're reading a book.

184
00:09:25.420 --> 00:09:27.580
Top to bottom, left to right,
front to back.

185
00:09:27.580 --> 00:09:30.670
So, starting at the top of the general
area, starting in the left,

186
00:09:30.670 --> 00:09:32.470
I choose general.

187
00:09:32.470 --> 00:09:36.520
Going, and this is interesting,
Dan, I wore the blue shirt today

188
00:09:36.520 --> 00:09:40.740
because blue is a very important
color in the Adobe interface.

189
00:09:40.740 --> 00:09:41.430
>> I did not know that.

190
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:43.850
>> It highlights what you're working with,
and

191
00:09:43.850 --> 00:09:48.450
occasionally if you see things
in blue you can change that.

192
00:09:49.470 --> 00:09:50.110
Okay?

193
00:09:50.110 --> 00:09:53.250
So that's very, very important.

194
00:09:53.250 --> 00:09:56.360
So start, it's like, at start up,
show the start screen.

195
00:09:56.360 --> 00:10:00.330
That's the thing that I just
walked everybody through.

196
00:10:00.330 --> 00:10:03.950
If you're one of those folks that wants
to just click on the premier icon,

197
00:10:03.950 --> 00:10:11.390
I just wanna get working, I can say just
open my most recent and go straight to it.

198
00:10:11.390 --> 00:10:16.950
The thing that's gonna be upsetting
about some of these settings

199
00:10:16.950 --> 00:10:23.820
is that these will take place
after you have activated them.

200
00:10:23.820 --> 00:10:25.990
So let's take, for example,
when opening a project,

201
00:10:25.990 --> 00:10:30.158
show the opening dialogue,
show the start screen.

202
00:10:30.158 --> 00:10:33.330
These are just, Adobe has defaulted it
to what they think is the most common.

203
00:10:33.330 --> 00:10:36.150
And in most cases, it is the most
common thing that you're gonna do.

204
00:10:36.150 --> 00:10:38.260
But you can change them.

205
00:10:38.260 --> 00:10:40.320
Video transition duration.

206
00:10:40.320 --> 00:10:42.630
Right now, if I create dissolves or

207
00:10:42.630 --> 00:10:46.770
any other transition,
it's going to be 30 frames.

208
00:10:46.770 --> 00:10:49.260
Nice thing is,
I can change that to seconds.

209
00:10:49.260 --> 00:10:52.030
And say I would like it to be
a certain amount of seconds,

210
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:55.560
like I want all of them to
be three seconds in length.

211
00:10:55.560 --> 00:10:57.140
Why?
I have no idea.

212
00:10:57.140 --> 00:10:59.620
So, I'll go back to frames and
just say, yeah, 30 frames.

213
00:10:59.620 --> 00:11:02.700
I can do that,
the same thing with audio transitions.

214
00:11:02.700 --> 00:11:06.700
I can say frames,
make that 30 frames or change it.

215
00:11:06.700 --> 00:11:09.750
Sometimes I like to do really
short audio transitions, so

216
00:11:09.750 --> 00:11:12.424
I'll make that a five, okay?

217
00:11:12.424 --> 00:11:14.060
Now, what this does not do.

218
00:11:15.090 --> 00:11:18.130
So, Dan, let's say I've already
created a sequence, and

219
00:11:18.130 --> 00:11:23.400
I have all of these nice little audio
transitions, and they're all 30 frames.

220
00:11:23.400 --> 00:11:27.170
And I say, I go back, and it's like
I wanted those to be five frames,

221
00:11:27.170 --> 00:11:28.240
and I change it.

222
00:11:28.240 --> 00:11:30.100
It changes nothing that I've already done.

223
00:11:31.410 --> 00:11:33.830
This will change what
I'm going to do next.

224
00:11:33.830 --> 00:11:36.180
>> So it won't take effect until you-
>> Won't take effect.

225
00:11:36.180 --> 00:11:38.670
>> Anything you've done before,
that's all still gonna be the same?

226
00:11:38.670 --> 00:11:40.221
>> Right,
it's all still gonna be the same.

227
00:11:40.221 --> 00:11:42.183
And that,
I know some people find that frustrating.

228
00:11:42.183 --> 00:11:45.455
But it's, then all I have to do is just go
get those out and put the new [INAUDIBLE].

229
00:11:45.455 --> 00:11:45.955
>> Well, I mean,

230
00:11:45.955 --> 00:11:48.492
it makes sense if you think about it
because Adobe's not assuming that you want

231
00:11:48.492 --> 00:11:49.960
to change everything you've already done.

232
00:11:49.960 --> 00:11:52.079
They assume that now that
you've changed a setting,

233
00:11:52.079 --> 00:11:53.940
you wanna change it from here on out.

234
00:11:53.940 --> 00:11:54.590
>> Exactly.

235
00:11:54.590 --> 00:11:59.340
Adobe wants you, their whole philosophy
is, they want you to create the story,

236
00:11:59.340 --> 00:12:02.380
they wanna help you create the story.

237
00:12:02.380 --> 00:12:05.900
And they feel like if they did that,
they'd be taking over the story.

238
00:12:05.900 --> 00:12:08.054
So, that's, I mean,
that's part of the psychology, and

239
00:12:08.054 --> 00:12:09.460
that's why I like working with this.

240
00:12:09.460 --> 00:12:11.270
Still image default duration.

241
00:12:11.270 --> 00:12:15.270
This is if you wanna do this really cool
thing like you bring in still photos and

242
00:12:15.270 --> 00:12:18.440
then you wanna animate them, and
make them fly and blow them up.

243
00:12:18.440 --> 00:12:22.640
Right now, every still image that I
bring up will be five seconds long.

244
00:12:23.780 --> 00:12:29.400
I can extend that to, let's say,
I want them to be 360 seconds.

245
00:12:30.680 --> 00:12:36.550
Yeah, I mean, I can make the still images
very, very long so I can work with them.

246
00:12:36.550 --> 00:12:38.897
These are where you start getting
into some real preference things,

247
00:12:38.897 --> 00:12:40.487
like timeline, playback, auto scrolling.

248
00:12:40.487 --> 00:12:45.420
I'm gonna go over later, cuz until you
see it, it doesn't make any sense.

249
00:12:45.420 --> 00:12:48.010
Same thing with vertical mouse scrolling.

250
00:12:48.010 --> 00:12:52.750
You might just find that there are certain
things that you do, that it's like

251
00:12:52.750 --> 00:12:57.030
I wanna be able to do this, and
you can make it happen here.

252
00:12:57.030 --> 00:13:00.430
Which is nice, it's really nice
that you can customize the system

253
00:13:00.430 --> 00:13:04.810
as much as you want, so that way,
you're focusing on the story.

254
00:13:04.810 --> 00:13:05.630
All right.

255
00:13:05.630 --> 00:13:10.470
Set focus on the timeline when
performing in certain overwrite edits.

256
00:13:10.470 --> 00:13:14.518
That is something that we're gonna, once
we start editing that you're gonna wanna

257
00:13:14.518 --> 00:13:16.890
see cuz this can be frustrating for
people.

258
00:13:16.890 --> 00:13:20.780
Some people like it one way,
some people like it the other.

259
00:13:20.780 --> 00:13:23.905
Basically, this is just
all general setting of

260
00:13:23.905 --> 00:13:27.365
how to make this thing work best for you.

261
00:13:27.365 --> 00:13:30.335
And general is the best way to start.

262
00:13:30.335 --> 00:13:33.915
The one that I really
want to focus on that,

263
00:13:33.915 --> 00:13:37.410
once I bring in some still photos
that I've shot, that you really,

264
00:13:37.410 --> 00:13:42.500
really wanna take a look at is this one
called default scale to frame size.

265
00:13:42.500 --> 00:13:48.140
In most cases, you want this off
because what you're looking to do,

266
00:13:48.140 --> 00:13:52.290
and I took some pictures
with a Canon 5D Mark III.

267
00:13:52.290 --> 00:13:53.100
>> That's a nice camera.

268
00:13:53.100 --> 00:13:55.500
>> Yeah, it's very nice and it's not mine.

269
00:13:55.500 --> 00:13:56.230
It's my friend's.

270
00:13:56.230 --> 00:13:58.930
He let me borrow it,
with a really nice lens.

271
00:13:58.930 --> 00:14:04.180
And this project is going to be,
I'm just gonna try and do this.

272
00:14:04.180 --> 00:14:05.000
It's gonna be like 1080.

273
00:14:05.000 --> 00:14:05.940
Okay, it's gonna be 1920 by 1080.

274
00:14:05.940 --> 00:14:12.100
These pictures are going to be
like huge compared to that.

275
00:14:12.100 --> 00:14:17.680
If I say default scale to frame
size is off, when I bring

276
00:14:17.680 --> 00:14:22.610
in those images, they're not going to
default size down to 1920 by 1080,

277
00:14:22.610 --> 00:14:27.380
they're gonna stay this size and that way
I can animate them, cuz they're oversized.

278
00:14:27.380 --> 00:14:29.350
Okay, they're gonna oversize that way.

279
00:14:29.350 --> 00:14:32.520
If I turn it on,
everything's gonna get reduced.

280
00:14:32.520 --> 00:14:33.930
And then,
I'm not gonna have the resolution,

281
00:14:33.930 --> 00:14:35.760
I'm not gonna be able to
play around with that.

282
00:14:35.760 --> 00:14:39.600
That is why it is automatically off.

283
00:14:39.600 --> 00:14:42.580
And that is why, in most cases,
you wanna leave it automatically off.

284
00:14:42.580 --> 00:14:44.350
Cuz you took these giant pictures.

285
00:14:44.350 --> 00:14:47.070
Why don't you just get in there and
animate them, okay?

286
00:14:47.070 --> 00:14:51.425
So, that's about all I'm gonna
do in the General section.

287
00:14:51.425 --> 00:14:52.195
Appearance.

288
00:14:52.195 --> 00:14:53.695
This one is hard, okay?

289
00:14:53.695 --> 00:14:57.065
This is a rough one.

290
00:14:57.065 --> 00:14:58.175
Okay, that's better.

291
00:14:58.175 --> 00:15:02.460
This is basically, do I want my
interface brighter, do I want it darker.

292
00:15:02.460 --> 00:15:05.020
I can change the highlight
color a little bit,

293
00:15:05.020 --> 00:15:08.900
I can make the kind of darker
[INAUDIBLE] interactive controls.

294
00:15:08.900 --> 00:15:15.150
It's really what you want and
what you like in terms of how your user

295
00:15:15.150 --> 00:15:18.648
interface appears in terms of light dark-
>> Gives you a personalization-

296
00:15:18.648 --> 00:15:20.690
>> Give you a little personalization,

297
00:15:20.690 --> 00:15:22.060
don't go too wacky.

298
00:15:22.060 --> 00:15:24.480
I've seen some really strange things.

299
00:15:24.480 --> 00:15:30.661
If it's so
bizarre that your head hurts, okay?

300
00:15:30.661 --> 00:15:32.655
I mean, it's like, okay?

301
00:15:32.655 --> 00:15:33.210
Audio.

302
00:15:33.210 --> 00:15:37.280
A lot of this can be fun to play around
with, but I will give you this right now.

303
00:15:37.280 --> 00:15:41.560
Most of what is set in here
is pretty much what you want.

304
00:15:41.560 --> 00:15:46.221
The thing that people want
to know initially is what is

305
00:15:46.221 --> 00:15:50.220
mute input during timeline recording?

306
00:15:50.220 --> 00:15:53.326
What is automatic audio
wave form generation?

307
00:15:53.326 --> 00:15:54.905
And what is this default audio track?

308
00:15:54.905 --> 00:15:57.890
This is the one that people
are most concerned with.

309
00:15:57.890 --> 00:16:00.604
So Mute input during
timeline recording means,

310
00:16:00.604 --> 00:16:06.050
remember I mentioned that I could do a
voiceover, I could read into a microphone.

311
00:16:06.050 --> 00:16:10.670
If this is off,
whatever audio might be in the timeline,

312
00:16:10.670 --> 00:16:15.115
like music or another person speaking,
I can hear In the headphones or

313
00:16:15.115 --> 00:16:18.845
through the computer speakers while
I'm trying to do this voiceover.

314
00:16:18.845 --> 00:16:21.915
So I might say, no, I don't want to hear
any of that or I'm gonna flub it up, and

315
00:16:21.915 --> 00:16:24.305
I had to do it 19 times and
I'm gonna have all these terrible files.

316
00:16:24.305 --> 00:16:25.995
So you can turn that off.

317
00:16:25.995 --> 00:16:31.330
Automatic audio waveform generation, I'm
sure if you've gotten into this before,

318
00:16:31.330 --> 00:16:34.230
you know that there's little audio
wave forms on the tracks, okay.

319
00:16:34.230 --> 00:16:38.730
You have the ability to turn it off,
in a sense.

320
00:16:38.730 --> 00:16:42.740
Why, you don't have enough RAM, okay,
you're working on a low computer, and

321
00:16:42.740 --> 00:16:45.630
you don't want them generated
until you absolutely need them.

322
00:16:45.630 --> 00:16:47.850
>> So this is all about
reclaiming some system resources-

323
00:16:47.850 --> 00:16:48.520
>> Saving some space.

324
00:16:48.520 --> 00:16:52.968
Saving some space for yourself,
also default audio tracks.

325
00:16:52.968 --> 00:16:56.968
When we get into audio this
is gonna start making sense,

326
00:16:56.968 --> 00:17:01.136
because a lot of what people
kind of get confused with, and

327
00:17:01.136 --> 00:17:06.600
I don't really blame you, in that Adobe,
you can have two audios in a clip.

328
00:17:07.610 --> 00:17:11.333
But then when you put it in a timeline,
you get one track, and

329
00:17:11.333 --> 00:17:13.094
that kind of throws people.

330
00:17:13.094 --> 00:17:15.120
And I'm gonna go through
the Adobe psychology.

331
00:17:15.120 --> 00:17:18.020
Once you get it down,
it's actually really nice

332
00:17:18.020 --> 00:17:22.870
to be able to just work in
single tracks but dual sources.

333
00:17:22.870 --> 00:17:26.860
But this gives you a chance to change that
if you don't like, if you want mono media

334
00:17:26.860 --> 00:17:33.320
to actually come in as mono and not
necessarily use the file's protocol, okay.

335
00:17:33.320 --> 00:17:36.840
So you get a chance to do that as well.

336
00:17:36.840 --> 00:17:38.501
Couple of things, the AutoSave.

337
00:17:38.501 --> 00:17:43.122
All right, this is where I’m saying
automatically do it every 15 minutes, no,

338
00:17:43.122 --> 00:17:44.600
do it every five.

339
00:17:44.600 --> 00:17:46.420
And let me see what the maximum is.

340
00:17:46.420 --> 00:17:48.790
I always like playing around with
how many are they gonna give me.

341
00:17:50.590 --> 00:17:53.089
I just did something that
really frustrates people and

342
00:17:53.089 --> 00:17:54.507
I wanted to demonstrate this.

343
00:17:54.507 --> 00:17:58.007
As soon as I entered a number, and

344
00:17:58.007 --> 00:18:03.450
did return,
it clicked out of the settings.

345
00:18:03.450 --> 00:18:06.940
This happens to me all the time,
okay, don't worry about this, okay.

346
00:18:06.940 --> 00:18:09.580
Can I do 999 and just click out?

347
00:18:09.580 --> 00:18:14.130
Yes, I can have 999 projects,
let's see if I can go higher.

348
00:18:14.130 --> 00:18:16.405
This is the funny,
this is the fun part about Adobe,

349
00:18:16.405 --> 00:18:17.922
is what are they allowing me to do?

350
00:18:17.922 --> 00:18:18.674
I'm going higher.

351
00:18:18.674 --> 00:18:19.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is great.

352
00:18:19.610 --> 00:18:23.516
So what this means is that on
the auto-saves, as soon as I hit 1,000

353
00:18:23.516 --> 00:18:28.160
auto-saves and I go to 1,001,
the oldest one then gets removed.

354
00:18:28.160 --> 00:18:29.110
>> So first in, first out?

355
00:18:29.110 --> 00:18:30.330
>> First in, first out.

356
00:18:30.330 --> 00:18:32.910
So, I could say I want so
many that the first in,

357
00:18:32.910 --> 00:18:37.360
first out isn't gonna take effect
until I have 1,000 backups.

358
00:18:37.360 --> 00:18:38.204
>> Gonna run out of storage space.

359
00:18:38.204 --> 00:18:39.705
[LAUGH]
>> Gonna run out of storage space.

360
00:18:39.705 --> 00:18:42.070
[LAUGH] The other thing I can also do,
oops, sorry about that.

361
00:18:42.070 --> 00:18:43.810
I love playing with this.

362
00:18:43.810 --> 00:18:47.540
I can save the backup to
my Creative Cloud account.

363
00:18:48.550 --> 00:18:51.470
Okay, save it to my Creative Cloud
account as well which is-

364
00:18:51.470 --> 00:18:53.116
>> It's doing it in conjunction with

365
00:18:53.116 --> 00:18:55.100
the save to the local source?

366
00:18:55.100 --> 00:18:56.460
>> So, I'll demonstrate that.

367
00:18:56.460 --> 00:18:58.399
I will demonstrate that
as we start working.

368
00:18:59.940 --> 00:19:01.550
Control Surface is another one.

369
00:19:01.550 --> 00:19:06.209
If you want to,
a lot of people like really nice

370
00:19:06.209 --> 00:19:10.761
color control services or
an audio service.

371
00:19:10.761 --> 00:19:12.167
You can add that here.

372
00:19:12.167 --> 00:19:16.150
You can also do some Device Controls
if you're working with the tape deck.

373
00:19:16.150 --> 00:19:19.160
So, if your deck sub type you
could control it from here.

374
00:19:19.160 --> 00:19:22.930
Labels, this is an interesting one.

375
00:19:22.930 --> 00:19:26.410
Everything gets a label, so if I go
down the Label Defaults, if it's a bin,

376
00:19:26.410 --> 00:19:29.810
it's mango,
if it's a sequence it's forest.

377
00:19:29.810 --> 00:19:31.300
I have to kinda go through this, people,

378
00:19:31.300 --> 00:19:33.910
this is fun cuz you can
color code everything.

379
00:19:33.910 --> 00:19:35.330
Sometimes I like color codes.

380
00:19:35.330 --> 00:19:39.460
I have a friend, he doesn't, so
he just changes all of these to white or

381
00:19:39.460 --> 00:19:42.940
another innocuous color which is fine,
which you can do.

382
00:19:42.940 --> 00:19:46.760
The thing that it does not do,
that kinda throws people.

383
00:19:46.760 --> 00:19:50.560
Let's say I go and I change this color and
I just change it to green.

384
00:19:52.210 --> 00:19:57.955
It still says violet, so it's not going to
change it to the name of the actual color.

385
00:19:57.955 --> 00:20:00.010
[LAUGH] So that's really
a label on the left-hand side.

386
00:20:00.010 --> 00:20:02.950
>> It's just a label on the left-hand side
and people get really upset about that.

387
00:20:02.950 --> 00:20:06.390
They're like, wait a minute, it's not
changed, well, it's not supposed to.

388
00:20:06.390 --> 00:20:10.910
So the label defaults are, the bin is
mango, the sequences probably can change,

389
00:20:10.910 --> 00:20:16.040
and I can say, no, I want bins to be
rose The thing that they do that I think

390
00:20:16.040 --> 00:20:20.890
is very nice, especially when you get your
sequence into the timeline, your video and

391
00:20:20.890 --> 00:20:22.740
your audio are different colors.

392
00:20:23.740 --> 00:20:27.277
So that way, occasionally when
you look at a sequence and

393
00:20:27.277 --> 00:20:30.526
you just see all the same color, you're-
>> What's what?

394
00:20:30.526 --> 00:20:31.162
>> What's what?

395
00:20:31.162 --> 00:20:32.295
It's like, colors.

396
00:20:32.295 --> 00:20:33.480
Colors work, so I can do that.

397
00:20:35.040 --> 00:20:39.740
Media, the only thing I really
want to cover in this one,

398
00:20:39.740 --> 00:20:44.280
if people wanna dig around into it later,
they can.

399
00:20:44.280 --> 00:20:49.700
Occasionally you have a thing called
a cache, and what this means is

400
00:20:49.700 --> 00:20:53.350
you might open up Premier and
down in the little right-hand portion

401
00:20:54.360 --> 00:20:58.780
of the user interface, there's this
little narrow line that just keeps going.

402
00:20:58.780 --> 00:21:00.450
It's building.

403
00:21:00.450 --> 00:21:03.600
You may have moved a drive somewhere or
you may have erased something.

404
00:21:03.600 --> 00:21:07.162
And what it's doing is it's
rebuilding waveforms or

405
00:21:07.162 --> 00:21:11.841
it's rebuilding some files that
are needed for things like H264.

406
00:21:11.841 --> 00:21:14.936
They're called cache files.

407
00:21:14.936 --> 00:21:20.090
Occasionally these build up and
you might have to clean them.

408
00:21:20.090 --> 00:21:23.410
And you just say clean them out and
start fresh.

409
00:21:23.410 --> 00:21:25.310
So that's what you wanna do.

410
00:21:25.310 --> 00:21:29.060
Now you wanna make sure that if
you're doing this with drives,

411
00:21:29.060 --> 00:21:32.090
you want the drive attached cuz it's
only gonna throw away the cache

412
00:21:32.090 --> 00:21:34.200
files that you don't need any more.

413
00:21:34.200 --> 00:21:38.525
If the drive's not attached, it's going
to throw away all the cache files,

414
00:21:38.525 --> 00:21:40.925
which is fine,
it just has to rebuild them.

415
00:21:40.925 --> 00:21:44.205
It just has to rebuild everything,
which just can be time consuming.

416
00:21:44.205 --> 00:21:46.005
Okay, that's just a timing issue.

417
00:21:47.895 --> 00:21:52.880
The next one is sync settings, cuz since
everybody's using the Creative Cloud now,

418
00:21:52.880 --> 00:21:55.190
how do you want to sync
your Creative Cloud?

419
00:21:55.190 --> 00:21:58.970
Which is a nice setting instead of
just saying we sync it this way.

420
00:21:58.970 --> 00:22:01.440
That's not what Adobe likes to do.

421
00:22:01.440 --> 00:22:06.120
Adobe likes to say no,
how do you want to do this?

422
00:22:06.120 --> 00:22:11.070
And you can say, I have the preferences,
the settings, the workspace layouts, and

423
00:22:11.070 --> 00:22:14.700
the keyboard shortcuts get saved.

424
00:22:14.700 --> 00:22:16.770
Those go to my Creative Cloud account.

425
00:22:16.770 --> 00:22:18.700
And then when syncing, ask my preference.

426
00:22:18.700 --> 00:22:22.540
Do I always wanna upload,
do I always wanna download settings?

427
00:22:22.540 --> 00:22:27.280
Or do I wanna say automatically clear
the settings on the application quit?

428
00:22:27.280 --> 00:22:31.340
Which means if I'm on someone else's
computer and my Creative Cloud's

429
00:22:31.340 --> 00:22:34.130
on there and it's like I'm gonna leave,
I want my stuff cleared off of it.

430
00:22:34.130 --> 00:22:35.370
It's not because I don't like them,

431
00:22:35.370 --> 00:22:37.420
but they're probably going to
say why is this stuff on here?

432
00:22:37.420 --> 00:22:38.393
That's very weird of you
to leave your stuff behind.

433
00:22:38.393 --> 00:22:39.478
>> Yeah.

434
00:22:39.478 --> 00:22:41.580
>> Which we are all
learning with the Internet.

435
00:22:41.580 --> 00:22:46.310
So, I have made a lot of these settings.

436
00:22:46.310 --> 00:22:49.580
I'm happy now, now what?

437
00:22:51.040 --> 00:22:54.410
Now, I'm gonna get in and I'm gonna
bring some media in this actual thing.

438
00:22:54.410 --> 00:22:57.546
And I think you and I are gonna end up
doing that next time where we actually

439
00:22:57.546 --> 00:23:00.737
bring in some media and play around
with this interface because you may say

440
00:23:00.737 --> 00:23:02.770
I don't, it's just moving everywhere.

441
00:23:02.770 --> 00:23:06.550
How do I make it look like something
that I want to use instead of this?

442
00:23:06.550 --> 00:23:10.290
>> Yeah, this is a little amorphous maybe.

443
00:23:10.290 --> 00:23:11.820
>> Well, you know, yeah.

444
00:23:11.820 --> 00:23:15.380
And so next time it's like how do I,
I just did all these settings so

445
00:23:15.380 --> 00:23:18.030
that it's internally awesome,
how do we do the settings so

446
00:23:18.030 --> 00:23:21.230
now it's externally awesome
is what we're looking at.

447
00:23:21.230 --> 00:23:22.270
>> Well, awesome stuff, James.

448
00:23:22.270 --> 00:23:24.900
It's gonna be a lot of fun,
great demonstrations.

449
00:23:24.900 --> 00:23:28.430
Now, that we've kinda gotten inside of
the car, we've looked at all the bells and

450
00:23:28.430 --> 00:23:31.570
whistles and knobs we can turn to see what
it's gonna do, and now we understand that,

451
00:23:31.570 --> 00:23:34.300

452
00:23:34.300 --> 00:23:37.060
James, looks like we've come
to the end of a great episode.

453
00:23:37.060 --> 00:23:39.080
We really appreciate you dropping by.

454
00:23:39.080 --> 00:23:42.240
>> We gotta come back cuz I wanna do
the next one cuz I've got this now.

455
00:23:42.240 --> 00:23:43.280
>> We are gonna come back.

456
00:23:43.280 --> 00:23:44.930
We're gonna have plenty more.

457
00:23:44.930 --> 00:23:48.060
But for this one though looks
like we run out of time.

458
00:23:48.060 --> 00:23:49.231
So you'll have to come back and

459
00:23:49.231 --> 00:23:51.269
see where James take us down
the Adobe Premiere road.

460
00:23:51.269 --> 00:23:52.937
>> Yes, do.

461
00:23:52.937 --> 00:23:55.329
>> That being said,
we're gonna again sign off for ITProTV.

462
00:23:55.329 --> 00:23:57.028
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

463
00:23:57.028 --> 00:23:58.019
>> I'm James Biddle.

464
00:23:58.019 --> 00:23:59.960
>> And we'll see you next time.

465
00:23:59.960 --> 00:24:08.180
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James take a look at Premiere's windows or Monitors. They show you how to move or resize the Monitors to personalize the interface layout. Next they demonstrate editing the Monitors and how to jump in and out of fullscreen with a keyboard shortcut. Finally they show you how to create your own custom keyboard shortcuts.
episodes.title: The Interface

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss the processes of Importing and Ingesting. They show Ingesting single and multiple files and Importing folders of media. They also discuss using the importance of using Premiere's Media Browser to bring in media instead of Finder or some other file explorer.
episodes.title: Importing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explain how to keep your Project Window organized for ease of use. This will include renaming media folders, renaming clips, using columns, and creating custom columns. They also start modifying original source files using the Premiere Media Browser.
episodes.title: Organizing Your Project Window

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James begin taking a closer look into the Source Monitor and basic editing. They start by creating a keyboard shortcut to cycle through the Monitors/Windows quickly, then they do some basic audio and video editing, showing you how to sync separate audio and video clips to create a segment for a Sequence in the Timeline Monitor.
episodes.title: Source Window and Basic Editing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss and demonstrate using the Timeline and Program Monitors/Windows. They also explain the use of In and Out points, duplicate shot markers, and lots of keyboard shortcuts.
episodes.title: Timeline and Program Monitor

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into performing Overwrite and Replace edits and the difference between the two. They also discuss and demonstrate doing a Matched Frame Replace.
episodes.title: Overwrite and Replace Edits

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James describe and demo Storyboard edits and Automate to Sequence. They start by creating a new Sequence and then perform Scaling and Set to Frame. Finally, they look at how to order the Sequence and create a video montage to the beat of an audio track.
episodes.title: Storyboard Edit and Automate to Sequence

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into Trimming, Moving, and Removing as edits. They start by demonstrating how to create Sub-clips which is like a form of Trimming. Then they show you how to reorder clips by moving them without creating gaps or overwriting. Finally, they look at trimming; removing unwanted bits of audio/video/both using the Trim Tools to perform Rolling and Ripple edits.
episodes.title: Trimming, Removing and Moving

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss speed changes in your sequence(s). They import a sequence from another project and show you how to perform a "Slip" or retime of a clip using the Slip Tool. They also demonstrate speeding up and slowing down using the Stretch tool.
episodes.title: Speed Changes

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explore adding visual effects to your project. Techniques covered include linear keyframe changes (zooming in/out of still images using keyframes), creating effect presets (reusing attributes on multiple stills so you don't have to redo the work), and adding effects to source media to modify all clips.
episodes.title: Visual Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James demonstrate implementing Transitions. They will show you how to add transitions like dissolves, wipes, 3d boxes and manipulate their affect/attributes more/less longer/shorter. Then they look at using Sync Lock and Clip Handles.
episodes.title: Transitions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James take a closer look at adjusting audio in Premiere. They begin by synchronizing audio tracks and how to use both clip and track keyframes. They also discuss track mixing and adding music using the Timeline as well as the Track Mixer. Finally, they demonstrate how to create a sub-mix.
episodes.title: Audio Adjustments

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James show you how to add effects to your audio tracks. They get started by working with track and clip keyframes, as well as the sub-frame view for fine tuning. Then they show the steps necessary to add effects like reverb, from the built-in effect plugins. Also discussed is the Loudness Radar tool and audio hardware compatibility and use.
episodes.title: Audio Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James show you how to add titles to your work by employing the Title Tool, aka The Titler. With the title tool, not only can you add titles but you can also add effects to your titles, which they show. They also show you how to work with the Typekit from the Adobe Create Cloud and explain the Title and Action Safe Area to keep your titles from getting clipped.
episodes.title: The Title Tool

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into performing color correction in Premiere. They start off by showing you how to set the black, white, and grey levels. Then they show you the 3-way Color Corrector and Luma tools. They demonstrate working with shadows, midtones, and highlights and the Color Window.
episodes.title: Color Corrections

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explain the processes of saving, exporting, and sharing your Premiere Pro projects. They begin by uploading your project settings to the Adobe Creative Cloud for use on later projects. Then they show you how to export your settings locally. Next, they demonstrate sharing your projects, whether in piece or in full. Lastly, they look at Edit Decision Lists(EDL), OMF for audio, Marker Lists, and a step-by-step export of media.
episodes.title: Saving, Exporting and Sharing
